text: At Bells brewpub. Their menu showed it with a 4.0% ABV. Hints of coffee, cocoa but really light. Roastiness, nuttiness--again pretty light. Overall an okay beer to drink with a meal, which I did. But not one I would enjoy otherwise.

Aroma is roasty, nutty, dry, chocolate or dry cocoa, old coffee, good. Appearance is brown, light brown head, reddish tint I can see through. Taste is dry, dry cocoa, roasty, nutty, coffee, good. Mouthfeel is medium body, light carbonation, nutty roasty aftertaste. Overall, solid dry stout.
Looks good, smells good....tastes like dark water. Dont know why its rated so high.

This one is smokey and chocolates. Strong roasted malt flavor back bone. Pours black with a thin tan head. Smells smokey and coffee flavored. Had at bells 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Draft pour at the source. Pours a darker brown with a beige head of foam. The aroma has mild roast and nuts. Taste is pretty faint, but a little toasty. Light body and moderate carbonation.

Pour on tap at the brewery, dark black pour with tan head, aroma brought notes of roast, earth, some nuts, hints of dark fruit, coffee, some slight cocoa powder, sweet molasses as well. Taste was oak, earth, molasses, coffee, some cocoa, finishing sweet, dries out well at the way end.

[6657-20140816] Bottle. Roasted peanut grains aroma. Black body with a quick foamy off-white head. Roasted grains and light cocoa dust flavour has a hint of barrel. Full body. Wow. (7/3/7/4/15) 3.6
(@ Campground Brewdown 2014, Millmont, PA)

Sampler at brewpub. Pours black with a khaki head. Leaves a lot of lacing in the glass. Not a ton on the nose. Definitely get some chocolate on the tongue. Not so sure about the oak although it finished pretty clean. Not bad.

Tap @ Bells: Solid, rich brown color, not quite black with a long lasting khaki film & foamy collar topping it off. Light aroma with hints of dry, roasted malts, dried coffee beans, & some unsweetened cocoa powder. Big roasted malt base in the flavor; very dry, hints of ash with lots of dry coffee beans & a mild cacao note to it, too. Theres a very, very faint bit of milkiness the lingers in the finish, otherwise this is a bonafide dry stout all the way. Nice roasted body, dry from front to back. Its like Guinness Draught Plus.

12 ounce bottle. Pours a pitch black color with a small beige head. A big heavy roast sourness in the nose, chocolate. The flavor is great: dry, earthy, dark chocolate, minerals, heavy roast, bitter dark coffee, some lactose. A bit light.

UPDATED: JUN 12, 2014 Dry stout at Eccentric cafe. Pours dark with a medium head. Aroma is mallty roastiness. Nice light mouthfeel with some dryness. Nice clean finish with lingering roasted malt. This version is 4%, major session beer .

Draft at Bells. Pours dark chocolate brown with minimal head. Aroma of chocolate. Taste is hints of chocolate, roast malt. All flavors somewhat muted. Could be indicate of a dry stout - a style on which I am not well versed.

On draft at All Stouts Day. Nitro infused.  The pour is a dark dark brown with the typical nitro head and amazing lacing as any nitro will do. The aroma is somewhat bland. Dry, somewhat hoppy, and a touch of the roast. The flavor is very similar. Dry, roasty, not a whole lot extra going on. The finish is a little dry, like the style would insinuate. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

On tap at Eccentric Café. Dark brown with ruby lowlights a rather thin tan topper. Aroma is faint and roasty with dark malts and mild cocoa. Thin bodied with light chocolate, roasted malts and a dry chalky finish.
Had this at their tap room in kalmazoo with Raith. Decent stout but not on a par with their other ones.

2002 vintage - solid aroma of coffee with a thin pour and lots of carbonation, dry taste and soft mouthfeel.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Draft.  Roasted barley malt aroma.   Brown-black with moderate head.   Light toasted barley malt flavor.   Solid.

On draft @ the brewpub.  Listed on the big board at 4%.  Pours an opaque dark brown with a frothy off-white head.  Not too much of a scent, slight roasted coffee.  Good amount of taste for the low alcohol content, coffee and chocolate, very dry.  A very drinkable session stout.
Good stout. Aroma of nut, coffee and roast malt. Good lacing and head. Bitter aftertaste. Medium carbonation, medium palate and good consistency. Tap at brewpub.

Draft to taster at Bells. Looks good; black with foamy beige head that dissipates into lacing fairly quickly. Smells soapy and malty with a hint of smoke; an odd combo. Tastes better than it smells with some roastiness. Average on the palate with a dry finish. Alright, but not really my style.
Light chocolate and roast notes in the aroma.  Black pour, average retention and lacing.  Flavor is mellow roast malts, chocolate, very drinkable.  Low-medium body, medium carbonation.
UPDATED: FEB 26, 2012 À la pompe au pub: Classique irish stout avec une dose magnifié de torréfaction et un fini bien sec. Très belle créature.
On tap at Bells Eccentric Cafe.  An all-round good stout.  Roasty, black, and dry in the finish.  Another good one, Bells.

UPDATED: FEB 21, 2012 On tap at the brewpub. Pours blac with a dark brown head that dissipates very quickly and nearly completely. Aroma has a nice dark roasted malt note with a hint of roast and bitter chocolate. Flavor has some light chocolate upfront with backing dark grains and roasted malts with a dry finish.

Sampler pour on tap at the brewpub (Kalamazoo, MI). Pours a rich blackish darker pour, brownish glowing edges show healthy glow. A smallish frothy offwhite head dies to a ring, laces small. Aromas are gentle toast, roast, and cocoa. Some smoothed out sweetness, dry soda bread nose, touches of toast and roast grow. Not very sweet. Initial is typical Irish, a touch of thickness up front offering cocoa, roast, dry toast, and soda bread like dryness. Clean and fairly drinkable, with a touch of thickness as its giddy up. Middle shows touches of smokey roast, grains, and oatmeal. Some gentle smoked barley, touches of coffee, cocoa, roast. Really quite pleasant with a touch of body. Finish is cocoa, lingering smoke, roast, dryness. The smokey element really wins me over here. Quite nice.

On tap at Bells. Lighter bodied with a pronounced roastiness. Not much sweetness. Thin but not watery. Bells knows what theyre doing with stouts, thats for sure. A nice easy drinker and a good food pairing type of brew.

Draft.  I thought this was a decent stout, but the body was not as expected ... a little thin, but may that is what they are going for here.  Otherwise, the aroma was rich with chocolate.  I will seek out to try again.

On tap at Meridian Pint during their Bells Night of Darkness event. Served in a snifter.

The pour brings a hazy, medium-brown brew with a thin light tan head and a thin collar after that falls. The nose is pretty good with some fairly-strong chocolate dominating and being followed by a bit of earth, light roast, and a touch of vanilla.

The flavor pulls back quite a bit and there is some chocolate behind a flavor that is mostly a bit woody and earthy. Interesting, but not all that grand. Feel is a bit thin for what this is, though not by a large amount. Pretty drinkable in the end, but not my favorite. Out of the four new ones I had, Milk Stout is crowned king.

Serving type: on-tap

Reviewed on: 12-22-2010

On-tap at the Cafe...The color is way too light for a stout, a dark clear copper with lots of amber, ugly and off for the style. A light tan head with bad retention and lacing...The aroma is light but good, lightly roasted coffee, a touch of smoke, black coffee finish. Not really balanced but good...The taste is a big improvement, light coffee, very creamy and smooth. Roast and nuts begin to dominate after a while. Super easy to drink.

A great brown ale, a terrible dry Irish stout which is what they told me this was.

Draft sample at MBGWF 2011. Poured black color with an average frothy light brown head that mostly lasted with good lacing. Good roasted coffee malt aroma. Medium body with a smooth dry texture with flat carbonation. Moderate toasted sweet flavor with a medium sweet finish of average duration. Solid drinkable dry stout.

12oz pour at Meridian Pint.  Pours a nearly opaque deep brown with a thin beige head.  Doesnt look like a stout.  Nose is nutty, yeasty, bread, grains.  Sweet, malty, caramel, bread, a little candy, some very obvious fruit.  Medium bodied, dry finish.  A little weird.  Not really a stout.

On tap.  Pour is deep brown with a large semi off white head.  Nice oak and roast malt in the aroma.  Taste is oak, cream, lingering chocolate, and slight bitter finish.  Creamy and semi dry finish.  Good and pretty interesting.

(draft @ Bells Eccentric Cafe - Kalamazoo, MI) Dark ruby red pour with a thin tan head. Nice and rich roasty flavor with some very mild chocolate. Mainly a delicious roasted aroma. Flavor has that really nice freshly ground coffee and freshly roasted coffee quality to it. Very well balanced as you get to the end. A bit thin-bodied but really flavorful.
draft: pours black with a thin white head, malty aroma, malty, coffee, dry and slightly bitter taste, fairly thin body

On tap at Eccentric. Dark brown body small head and aromas of coffee and bitter chocolate. Flavor is bitter chocolate and coffee with peat like eartiness. Full body and palate. Very nice to see this being served again.
user_location: The Wet Side of a Dry Town, Pennsylvania, USA

text: On tap at the Eccentric cafe 11/11/09. Pours dark brown with a thick tan head. Aroma is not real strong, but what is there is of chocolate, roasted malt and some coffee. Flavor is very good of the aforementioned. To me it tastes like a somewhat stronger Java stout, but not as creamy as a Breakfast Stout. Very good though all in all.

Sampled at the Ohio group tasting on DLD eve 09.  Thanks Dan!  Brown pour with a medium tan head.  Aroma of roasted malt, coffee and a touch of sweetness.  Malty flavor with some coffee, but its kinda thin.  I think this one may be a bit past its prime.  Held up better than some others would have though.

Name: Trumpeter Stout
Date: April 25, 2009
Mode: Bottle
Source: Tasting
Appearance: dark brown, wispy tan head
Aroma: dry chocolate and roasted aroma
Flavor: dry chocolate flavor, roasted character, light earthyness, light bitter finish
Aroma: 5/10; Appearance: 6/10; Flavor: 5/10; Palate: 6/10; Overall: 10/20
Rating: 2.6/5.0Drinkability: 6/10
Score: *4
Deep brown with amber highlights. Aroma is very smokey with coffee and caramel. Taste is of cocoa, coffee, and spices.
Thanks AgentSteve.  Dark brown, dark chocolate, wood, molasses, little darkfruits, little coffee.
Pours deep brown with a tan head. Nose is chocolate, wood and molasses. The flavor is quite the same with a bitterness present.

12 oz bottle from hellomynameis, Thanks!!! Nose of coffee, chocolate, and some old, dried, leathery prunes; Very dark brown with a medium tan head; flavor a little acidy and cardboardy but lots of coffee, chocolate, and dark fruit. Wish I had this fresh!
Bottle shared at a tasting.  Deep brown body with a a bitter coffee start, chocolate, coca, and a creamy finish with mineral accent.  Decent beer.

From a 12oz Bottle.  Courtesy of ryan.  Mostly transparent, dark cocoa brown color with a thin finger of fizzy ivory head.  Aromas of coconut bark, chocolate, and faint leather.  Hints of coffee and charred prune.  Oxidized, but not devastated.  Medium light bodied, sparkling carbonation with a thin body.  Flavors of milk chocolate and roast up front, with some prune fruitiness.  Finishes thin, with a mildly acidic coffee flavor lingering in the finish.  Obviously past it’s prime at this point, but still drinkable and certainly a nostalgic pleasure to taste again after being a favorite during college.  Thanks, Ryan!

Thanks to iowaherkeye for bringing this bottle to his farewell to Iowa tasting. Poured a garnet brown color with a light tan head. Smelled of roasted malt, subdued chocolate brownie, and a hint of anise. Medium bodied with roasty bitterness, coffee, a bit of white paper, and some light detracting acidity.
Bottle from Iowaherkeye - thanks Joey.  Sweet and dark malt aromas. Liquorice.  Dark, dark brown.  Flavor is dry, slight vinegar, coffee/espresso, some chocolate.  Creamy dryish finish.

Deep black body with a quite big bubbled not  lasting beige head; Amazing chocolate nose, both full fat aromas and dry fine; The body is broken or maybe just way over the top, super thin and biting acid; Some oily chocolate aromas in the finish, but all you really think about is the bitting sourness.

12oz Batch 2646, shared with my GF Cyn.  Pours blackish brown with a 1 finger tan head.  nose is really nice and and full of chocolate.  Taste is dry and full of chocolate, really a pretty nice stout.

Bottle courtesy of tetrik -- thanks for sending this retired gem my way! Sampled June 2008 -- when was it retired? Its held up well. 
Pours a deep near-black brown with a grey-brown head that is refreshed as I sip from the intense (though not particularly prickly) carbonation within.

Powerful and very appealing aroma -- this is really something -- of salted Swedish licorice, fresh foam on a French press coffee, bakers chocolate. Rich flavor with the roasty nutty and slightly sourness combination that Ive experienced in this measure only with  roasted cacao nibs. A bit more sour on the finish, perhaps showing its age, but on the long end the chocolate and coffee comes back, leaving this beautiful aftertaste of a strong chocolate bar. Awesome beer. Im really glad to have had the chance to try this.
bottle, dark brown to black in color, coffee nose with a light brown head, spritzy palate with roast flavors of pork rinds
Dark brown to black in color and clear.  Dark, rich, roasted, coffee, chocolate in the aroma and the taste.  Some sweetness there.  Medium body.
Purchased six pack from Bells during the 12 Stouts of Xmas.  Solid dry stout - certainly better than the Kalamazoo Stout, and something I could drink all day.

Bottle. Deep black in color with no head. Roasty caramel malty aroma. Chocolatety toffee nutty notes. Malty roasty chocolatey flavor. Caramel notes. Finish is roasty. Medium bodied. Decent beer. Drinkable.

Pours a dark brownish black, almost cola like,  with a reddish hue and a small white beige head.  Aroma of bitter chocolate notes, nuts, and faint coffee beans.  Taste of bitter chocolate, roasted malt, nuts and coffee beans.  Has held up decently.

2-21-08 bottle shared with lb4lb thanks to kramer17801!! 

Black brown in color with very carbonated white head.  Smell is roasted coffee, vanilla bean, and chocolate.  Flavor is actually very nice, but just muted.  Dry taste.  Flavor isnt too sweet - but has a roasted Nutella aspect in there.  Flavor has hazelnuts present.  Not usually something I would like but it works in this.  Watery iced coffee mouthfeel.

Big thanks to kramer17801 for the chance to try this one.
Pours almost black, with ruby edges and a lasting beige head that gives lacing.  Smell is hazlenut, roasty malt, and cream.  Taste is dark bitter, burnt roast in a very pleasant way with bits of coffee, and cream.  Thinnish body and nice medium carbonation, but it works very well in this beer and doesnt detract.  Super drinkable and reminds me of something like an iced hazlenut coffee.

12 oz bottle, via Puddintane.  Pours a very dark brown body, almost black, with a small fizzy light brown head that faded pretty quickly.  The nose is still wonderful.  Nice chalky roast with dark chocolate fudge, really reminds me of Tootsie Rolls.  The flavor is showing some age though.  A light lactic sourness overlays the roast and chocolate, but leaves the slight chalky yeastiness.  Some lingering cocoa powder notes.  Mouthfeel is medium bodied and maybe thinning out a bit with fizzy prickly carbonation.  Overall, this is clearly on the way down hill, but still enjoyable enough to drink, especially if youre a fan of Harveys Imperial Stout.
Bottle from Goldtwins. Pours totally flat, no head. A nice roasty coffee rind aroma. Lightly lactic, lightly sour, chalky falvor. A touch odd, definitely old tasting, but still tasty.

12oz bottle from Puddintane, muchas gracias. Pours dark brown with plenty of light coming through, very small off-white head. Smells roasty, toasty with a hint of coffee. Palate is thin with nice active carbonation. Pretty damn good stout. Not as smooth as some others, but tasty.

NorCal December 07 - Thanks to Moejuck for sending me this one. Its been out of the rotation of Bells line-up for quite sometime now, so the beer has some obvious age on it. Still, it wasnt bad. Not the greatest at all, but drinkable (barely). The aroma on the beer is sweet malts, chocolate and bell pepper. Appearance is dark brown with some light getting thru suprisingly. Filtered maybe? The taste is an odd combo of chocolate, roasted malts, and lactic sourness. Cant say Im disappointed at all, because the things really been out of date for awhile. Thanks to Joe again for letting me give it a go.

Bottle from sliffy. Pours  dark brown with garnet highlights. No head and lacking defined lacing. Cant smell much, slightly woody, some wet cardboard is evident, as is some cocoa that has mostly faded. Flavor is light with more wood, some lactose, and distinct tartness with a little bit of lemon and lime in the finish.  Kind of watery as a lot of the flavor seems to have faded. Smooth, but not in the best way. A little bit of a disappointment.  Oh well, its 5 years old.

Bottle, courtesy of Jeffin7. Dark brown, leaves a foamy ring around the glass. Nice chocolate, mocha nose. Interesting - even though the flavor is light in nature, it has a prominent tastiness of mocha/chocolate and some toffee-like toastiness underneath. Medium/light bodied with moderate carbonation. This bottle is a few years old and has held up rather nicely.

Bottle courtesy of Puddintane.  Pours dark brown with a thin white head.  Smells of rich chocolate, coffee, lots of roast, dark fruit, touches of oak and milky.  Tastes of coffee, some spice, figs, caramel, a hint of cherries.  Mouthfeel is thick and the finish on this one yields some great roasty malt.  I cant get over how rich the malt profile is on this one.  Bells never ceases to amaze me.

Poured from a 12 oz.  Muddy oak pour with a golden scotch shade around the rim.  Well-rounded and authentic chocolate and espresso aroma; tender and rich, leading into cinnamon toast and raisin.  Flavor bites with a mild coffee acridity, wet wood, black licorice and a soft touch of french toast.  Age has certainly affected it, but to no disastrous end; rather it seems to have provided a softening or tempering influence.  This probably fulfilled its purpose a couple years in, and by now has polished away some of the raw rustic  character of the malt.  Soft and rich palate betrays the glint of oxidation, if slightly.  Still, the remnant of roasts is bold; lingering, and glazed with a hint of red apple peel.  Graceful.  Thanks for sharing, Jeff!

bottle shared by dickinsonbeer.  Dark brown in color.  Aroma is carboardy malts, light sourness, roast, and chocolate.  Taste is roast, chocolate, cardboard, moderate sour fruit.  This bottle I guess just didnt age too well.

2002 bottle, special thanks to styles!  Poured a hazy, medium chocolatey brown with a short cap of yellowy-beige head.. left some sticky lacing as it descended.  Aroma clearly changed a bit.. picked up some spicy and sour notes to accompany the dry-roasted chocolate character.. some coffee and nutty notes in there too.  The flavor had a well-roasted semi-sweet chocolate and cocoa base along with a milder coffee.. lactic sourness and a dry, oaky bitterness accent the edges.. left a sour roasted cocoa finish.  Somewhat thick on the palate with great balance between the light bitterness, the roast, and even the changes due to age.. almost syrupy and quite dry at the finish.  Really enjoyed this, and I hope they brew it again!

12oz bottle, courtesy of artusory.  Thanks, Ryan!  Pours a dark brown color; light tan head with fine-bubbled lacing.  Pleasant, toasted malts and cocoa in the aroma.  Medium-to-full mouthfeel: milk chocolate creaminess, with a lively, dry cocoa base; plenty of chocolate and toasty malts with a slight, chewy viscosity.  Lengthy, cocoa and slightly nutty finish.

Dark brown/black with a tiny light tan head. The aroma is terrific, roast, chocolates, light coffee, vinous with just a touch of oxidation. Flavor is cola, roast, light chocolate, light espresso and fairly dry. Medium body is soft with light carbonation. Excellent.

Bottle: Poured a dark brown to black in color with an off white head. Aroma, roasted malts and coffee when it was first poured, but as it warmed up it took on some fruity notes. Flavor, fruity and vinous to start, sweet with some roasted malts, and some coffee. This has really aged well.

medium brown color With a large off white head. Awesome aroma of chocolate, vanilla, and some lightly burnt and roasted malts. Palate is a bit thin but not surprising for a beer of this age. taste has some notable sweetness and hints of that vanilla and roasted malts. There is a bit of age on this for sure but it has held up well and is a real treat to have tried.

dark brown body with a slight reddish hue...minimal head...aroma fo sweet malts, nuts, and perhaps lactose..somewhat sour body with light roasted malts, nuts, toast and marshmallow..very dry finish...baltic porter-like in many ways (a not so great one anyways)

Bottle from Styles.  Aroma of chocolate and cashews--a tough combination to beat.  Black in appearance with a thin head.  The palate is medium.  Dry roasted/burnts malts start things off.  Some light chocolate flavors, and a tangy finish.  Not bad.

Head is small statured, light brown and mostly fizzy. It does leave some head behind though. Nose of roast, chocolate, a light nuttiness and a hint of diacetyl. Full/medium body, lightly creamy. Buttery notes up front(not a problem) followed by some nice coffee and roast flavors. Light cherry and vanilla flavors appear as it warms. Dry, roasty finish. Seems to of held up well for a lighter alc. content brew, though i,m not really sure how old it is. Props to  robertsreality for the trade!

I am pretty sure this bottle is from BBB63. It has been sitting in the cellar for a long time. I always dread drinking retired beers because, more than likely, I will only be able taste it once.  Not sure when the beer was made, but I am pretty sure this bottle has a couple years behind it.Tasted, right from the cellar, at ~48° in an english pint glass. The color is dark brown , nearly black, with a short lived, light khaki head the just hugs the side of the glass now. There is some sediment near the bottom  of the glass, but it will not be evident until the glass is nearly empty.  The aroma is dark roast, chocolate, molasses, espresso. Smells good. The initial taste is roasted malt;  followed by more roastiness with mild, bittersweet chocolate and coffee and  light citrusy fruit flavors. The finish is astringent, acidic, and dry. The beer suceeds at being a dry stout. This is the best Dry Stout I have ever had.

Rating #1,600. 12oz bottle acquired in trade with robertsreality (thanks!). Poured a dark and cloudy brown color with a large sized tan head. Aromas of roasted malts, chocolate, wood, and coffee. Tastes of roast, chocolate, and some coffee. Flavors on the weaker side compared to the aromas. A very, very light sourness to it. Thinner body.

Bottle, snifter.  Very dark-almost black-brown hued beer with a moderate, foamy, light tan head.  A little light colored for a stout, in my opinion.  Chocolate, coffee and roasted malt provide both sweet and bitter aromas.  Nearly as strong is a note of honey butter.  Following that, some prune, vanilla and vinous aromoas and just a touch of smoke.  The butter part is a little strong for me, but not terribly so.  Starts off with a moderate chocolate and caramel sweetness and a buttery/fruity tang.  Finishes with a roasty coffee bitterness and the same tang.  Mineral like sourness as it warms.  Soft, slick textured medium body with average carbonation.  Dry stouts rarely flip my switch.

Old as hell but the price is right,  .99 cents.Nice dark brown color,small tan head that had a good hang time then faded slowly to leave a slight lace behind.The aroma was malty and roasty with a bit of coffee.The flavor was malty and roasty again with a decent coffee flavor and maybe a bit of chocolate coming through and a slight bitter side towards the end.Not a bad brew at all and well worth trying again.

Sampled on 8/31/05:  Nearly opaque dark brown color with a thin off-white head.  Grainy, lightly roasted aroma has some mild cooked vegetable presence.  Body is thin, lightly roasty and malty with some hints of dark fruit and a touch of tartness.  Probably aged ok, but has sadly passed its prime.  I really wish Bells would come back with the November Stouts.
(bonus brew from suiiy)pours a black body with dark brown edges.aroma is acidic coffee.flavor is a bit of the same with a sour finish.possibly another brew that was send to me past its prime.

Poured dark brown with a thin off-white head.  Roasted aroma of unground coffe beanns, some ash, and light notes of loose leaf paper.  Roasted and acidic flavor with a semi-dry finish.  Somewhat fizzy mouthfeel.

pours a dark brown w/ chunkies floating and a small off white head w/ some good lacing and some signs of carbonation on the glass.  Aroma is a big malt nose then raisens oak and some chocolate.  The palate was creamy and thick w/ a good coating.  The flavor was first a big roasted malt hints of chocolate a light bitterness hints of oak and other dryness with a touch of lactic acid ias well.  This bottle was starting to show a little sign of going bad but I think I beat it to it.

An unclear brown beer with a disappearing orange head. The aroma is of roasted malt and alcohol. The flavor is sweet malty with notes of prunes, wood, and over ripe fruit. The end is dry, but the body is thin.

Muddy brown colored, thin off-white head. Dominating coffee aroma with chocolate cake notes. Interesting but slightly artificial. Harsh roasted malt and fruit flavor. Rather unbalanced and dry as hell.

Thanks to robertsreality for this beer.

Poured black with a fizzy off-white head.  Very nice aroma of roasted coffee and dark fruits.  Taste is most predominantly bitter roasted coffee, with fruity acidity in the finish.  The body is decent for the style.  Overall nowhere near Bells best, but a good beer, and Im very thankful for having the opportunity to taste this retired item.
Dark brown. Powerfull chocolate aroma. Lacks power. A bit too dusty. The finish is a bit too watery and thin. Not dry.

Bottled: Brown/red coloured. Light brown head. Light roast, sweets, berries and coffee in the aroma. Flavour is roasted, hoppy, has light cocoa and coffee notes. Medium body. Is fruity and coffeish in the end. This a light challenging beer. I quite like it.
Bottled. Brown coloured. Loads of chocolate in the aroma. Very light flavour and mouthfeel. Notes of coffee and chocolate. Rather dry.

Black, with a small fleeting head that ringed the top of the glass.
Chocolate and coffee aroma. Well balanced flavor of roast malts with a coffee finish. Bells seems to be going in the right direction. Thanks to Wohlfs for giving me the chance to try this historical brew before it lost all of its good points.

The aroma had bittersweet chocolate, roastl, and coffee.  THe flavor had roast, coffee, slight dark fruit and chocolate.  THe beer poured an opaque color w/ thin lasting head and lacing.  The mouthfeel was full but watery.  Thanks Vac.

Pours with a dark brown body with red tinting topped by a thin head with little lacing.  The aroma is sweet and full of unsweetened (bakers) chocolate notes with a slight roastiness, as well as, a touch of fruit.  The flavor is sweet and slighlty bitter with nice roasty notes and a touch of chocolate.  Medium bodied yet a little thin and smooth.

Poursa deep brown hue with a light tan head.  Aromas of chocolate, espresso to be exact, some dark chocolate and a little milk and a hint of pepper.  Flavors of the same with a flowery finish.  Very light bitterness.

Bottle courtesy of styles: Dark brown with a small tan head that quickly diminishes after the pour.  The aroma is interesting - malty dark vinous fruits, coffee, toast, chocolate, acidic roasted malt, and an almost light whiskey scent (not alcohol though).  Medium bodied, oily, spritzy carbonation, body seems like it gets a little thin towards the finish.  Taste is vinous plum, grapes, acidic dry roasted malt, pepper, bitter chocolate, hint of sweet grapefruit in the background, fruity yeast, and light apple juice.  Theres a light sourness throughout this beer that compliments the flavors very nicely, as well as keeping this stout dry.  Finishes dry, bitter and just ever so slightly sour with roasted malt notes later on.  Id love to see how this tastes after a few more years in the bottle.
Pours black with little head. Big coffee aroma and taste and not much else. Little too watery, but is leaving lace on the glass, strange indeed. Finishes a little too sour.

Root-beer brown pour, with diminsihing off-white head on this beer. Strong roasted coffee, toast, hazlenut, and bittersweet chocolate. A rich, dusty coffee flavor. Not much background. A little bit of sweetness and a good hint of bitterness on the back end. Finishes smooth and lightly oak. Drinkable, with the palate being a little thin. Good Dry Stout!

Bottle courtesy of Mr. Michigan Brews:Styles. yeah this is a little outdated but it still has a nice roasted malty-smokiness to it,got some bitter chocolate to.I have had this before and know what it was like.This one has soured a little but I will rate this as I had it before,sorry purists.
Smells of chocolate with hints of caramel. Very bitter and with a dry after taste.

Pours black with a fairly thin tan head.  Aromas of coffee, roasted malts, yeast, and hint of sour fruits.  Tastes of strong coffee and a sweet sourness that accompanied the other flavors well.  Nice coating left in the mouth.

Bottle supplied by The_Fat_Kid.  Deep brown chestnut with the ruby colors only when backlit.  Smallish tan head forms and then fades  to a ring around the edge of the glass.  Minimal lacing.  Coffee and roasted malt aroma.  Perhaps hints of yeast.  Lighter bodied and a bit thin.  Light flavors of roasted malt.  Carbonation is still present in this older bottle.  Fair.

Bottle:  Lots of chocolate and coffee with a relatively strong smoke presence.  Pours dark brown, virtually black, with a tan head that diminishes quickly.   Strong sour presence from start to finish with some coffee added in the finish.  Dont like sourness in my stouts so thats really going to hurt this one.  Thanks to Styles for this one.

Pours oily black with minimal tan head. Nose is quite chocolatey with a bread-like maltiness.  Flavor is bitter chocolate , raisiny, robust yetundertones of coffee and smokiness.  Slight tart or sour finish.

Black with transluscent, ruby highlights.  This is paler than many American, robust porters.  The head is tan and collapses quite quickly for a Bells beer.  Seductive, espresso roast aroma with just a touch of real cream and a slight sourness.  Meduim/light body of diluted espresso, slight sourness, and a rather solid bitterness and an underlying smoke.

Bells.  Bells.  Bells.  The Bells.  My favorite poem of Edgar Allen Poe.  And one of my favorite breweries.  Some great stouts for this Stoutie and this was one of them.  Nice black body with just a tad of tan head.  Aroma of coffee, cherry, slight oaky smoke, milk chocolate.  Not as much body as I like in a stout but not bad.  The flavor echoed the essences that caressed the nose.  Very good stuff.

Pours a medium dark brown, thick off white head. Aroma is strong of coffee, and oak. Very nice Aroma. Flavor is subtle, of coffee, roast, and smoked oak. Dry finish, very impressive stout. The aging has done this one justice. Thanks to BBB63 for this tasty brew!

Thanks to hey_kevin for sharing this one. Aroma of dark molasses, roasted coffee and a bit of dark chocolate.  Flavor was of the same and carried to the bottom of the glass.  A bit of dryness towards the finish.  I wish hey_kevin had another bottle

I am not sure how many different stouts Bells makes but I havent had a bad one yet. This one had the most flavorful coffee taste of all of them Ive had. Almost worth moving to Michigan for. I love these guys.

Thanks to BBB63 for this one.  Pours dark brown with some burgundy and a big, off-white head.  Aroma is malt, fruit, chocoff, cabernet.  Tastes malty, with a big chocoff, fruity flavor (berries, melon), some hops, cabernet, and a roasty, smooth finish.  The palate is extremely smooth, medium-bodied.  This is a rock-solid stout.

A dark, cool and funky trumpeter, much like Miles Davis, sweet brown sugar and mollases nose, brown body with a semi lacey white head, woddy brown sugar taste, sour finish possibly b/c of how old this is, Im glad I got a chance to try this one before it vanishes completely.
aroma is very bready with an abundance of roasted barley.  very soft and mild for a complex stout.  very dry, slightly coffee-ish  finish.  good stout.
Dark with almost no head. Aroma is malt and saltine crackers. Flavour is bitter, bready, chocolate, etc. Finish is acidic but smooth, like turkish coffee.
dark ruby smooth tan head that didn't last long, chocolate and raisin with some malt watery mouth feel not to bad of a beer one of those you can drink a few of

Again, the Kalamazoo company confounds with their meager facts about their unusual brews. What makes this a "Trumpeter's" stout? Was it handed down from an old New Orleans recipe favored by Buddy Bolden? Was the brewmaster scared by a swan? Does it make you feel as cool as Miles Davis when you drink one? Will anyone tell me?
Totally black, with thin, tan head. Potent aroma here, very roasted, plus? smokey, figgy, raisiny...Acceptable texture, though not too complex on the palate. Smokiness carries through, though. Very pleasant, reminds me so much of the classic Irish dry stout style. I'd have one anytime, especially 'Round Midnight.

Slightly bitter aroma, but also chocolate, yeasts, and a "hard" bread aspect.  Dark brown color with hints of ruby around the edges.  When held up to the light, it turns dark red and carbonation is visible.  Small off white head and a small amount of lacing. An average taste.  Bitter coffee, some of that dark, "hard" bread with the yeasts. Kind of thin on the palate.  A good stout, but nothing spectacular, espically from a stout heavyweight such as Bells.

I ws hyped, but for some reason let down by this brew.  It was decently light and not as bold as say their rye stout or spiced stouts.  It just wasn't original enough for me to like it over some of their other wonderful creations.

Pours a dark brown with some head but no lacing. I was expecting a lot darker than this.

Smells like coffee and a bit of chocolate, but the smell is rather weak.

Tastes weak as well. The first thing I thought of when I tasted this was...sunflower seeds. There's a bit of coffee and chocolate there, but I'll be damned if I can't keep coming back to sunflower seeds to discribe the taste

Mouthfeel is actually pretty watery. I expected quite a bit thicker from Bell's. Drinkability is average. It's not a bad beer, just nothing special.

Bottle pours dark brown w/tannish highlights, miniscule cream colored head, and decent lacing. &nbsp Aroma is of coffee & chocolate brownies, heavy on the brownies. &nbsp Not sure whether to either drink this one or eat it! &nbsp Initial taste is musty, perhaps earthy, with some ground coffee beans thrown in. &nbsp Mouthfeel is a bit thin, perhaps common among dry stouts? &nbsp Finish is dry and a tad bitter(hoppy), with a hint of unsweetened dark chocolate.  OH, can't forget the coffee grinds. &nbsp Wishing the chocolate flavor came out a bit more. &nbsp Still a good brew tho! &nbsp Thanks goes out to acrodizer for the trade!
Smells and tastes like mild chocolate and coffee.  Disappointed in the thin body, but the soft woody coffee flavors were nice.

Dark ruby red with thick beige head and light islandic lacing. The aroma has lots of fruit and a light smoky and roasted coffee smell. The flavor is also well balanced, very delicious, slightly tart and sweet. Oak is present in this and a touch of port. Finishes dry and full-bodied.

Dark mahogany with lighter edges a big frothy head of off white. Nice lacing.  Chocolate, roast malts, mocha, and grape/raisin in the aromas.  Very nice flavors of again roast malt and mocha. Some chocolate shows up again, along with some toffee or caramel, can't make up my mind. A woody or earthy flavor is lingering as well. Nicely balanced and complex at the same time. Dry and creamy palate with a nice and hoppy finish. Very delectable.

Dark brown color with hazy edges. Vigorous pour produced a thin loose bubbled dark khaki colored head that crumbled down quickly to leave some spots of lace sticking and a firm ring throughout consumption. Aroma is lightly tangy and sweet of roastyness with touches of cocoa and coffee. Gains even more sweeter tones as it warms. Taste flows from the nose with the same sweet tangy sweetness mostly thats kinda dark cherryish or oaky, with a roasted malt overlay and some lightly playful notes of cocoa and strongly blended old coffee bitterness and light dryness creep off the end but the finish gets a bit empty before more light roasted coffee dryness and twinge slightly peaks again late. Feel is a bit thin with some wateryness in there, it has some peaks and valleys for sure, gains some roasty tanged feel and lightly velvety texture, thins out, grabs some dryness, thins out again, and then another nab of dryness comes in and continues to linger with some sweet notes. A weird ride and not all that great really, my first lulling disappointment from the folks at Bell's. And again I'm reminded of the Cherry Stout "with a twist" idea what with the Rye and Susie's Sweet Stout's being similar as well. How old was this bottle I wonder? Anyways...glad I was able to get it since its no longer brewed...at least this year?

Opaque, dark brown with a whispy tan head. Aromas of dark roasted malt and earthy tannins. Flavours of dark roasted malt, licorice and semi-sweet chocolate. Palate is initially bitter, then sweet with a dry finish.

Picked this up at Chucks fine wine and cheese shop in Chagrin Falls.  The gentleman said it has been in their cooler since last year.  Sure does seem to have aged well. Aroma is oozing with roasted chocolate.  One of the best noses to a beer I've experienced in a while.  The color is the standard black with a thin cream head to it.  This seems more like a sweet stout than a dry stout.  It doesnt have a chalky complex to it, it is more of a silky smooth feel than anything else.  The end is the only place that has any real bite to it.  In finish it has a slight coffee feel to it.  One of the best stouts I've had in a while.
Light smokey aroma and light brown color.  Big head.  The taste was smokey with some tartness, and the mouthfeel was light.  A good, but not a great stout.
tasty.  great coffee aroma.  smoked coffee, unsweetened chocolate flavors.  pretty complex.... i don't think my notes are thorough enough.  i really liked how the flavors kept lingering in my mouf.
Black body with small tan head.  Aroma is medium sweet, roasty, cherry, light smoky.  Taste is medium sweet, roasty, light cherry, finishing smoky.  Lovely medium body.

Large beige head with dark slightly reddish hue.  Smokey and roasty aroma.  Soft finish.  Flavor is malty and slightly dry.  Good flavor, with a very light palate.  Nice balance and even though it is not really the kind of stout that I like but I really enjoyed this beer.

Typical stout black with no head to speak of. Smells of coffee and bread? Flavor profile is quite dry and has a cracker/bread like quality. Interesting, but not my cup of "coffee" nice finish, however
There was a good amount of sediment in the bottle I had.  Still, a good beer that I'd buy regularly if I could get it in my area.

Ah the beauty of a stout in your glass, all atramentous in color with the crown all frothy and light chocolate in color and after its decomposition, the velum like curtain of lace that clings so lovingly to the glass. How bout dat nose? Coffee, sweet milk chocolate, malt and quite sweet what a treat for both the olfactory and ocular senses, with the front rich in malt and lightly sweet. Top is moderate in its feel to the palate and the finish delightful in its mild acidity, hops are pleasing and not overpowering, droughty aftertaste that continues the sweetness, a nice middle of the road stout, one that might just please the Lager Lovers?

UPDATED: NOV 30, 2003 A very dark brown with mahogany hilghlights and a thin white head.  Coffee dominates the amazing aroma, with chocolate and roast in the background.  Light on the palate with a decent amount of carbonation.  Flavor has a slight acidic sourness to it, but it also has a light sweetness to it.  The flavor consists of roast, coffee and chocolate notes.  Unfortunately the flavor and palate do not quite live up to the glorious aroma, but it is still a very good stout overall.
Powerful aroma of coffee.  Very dark brown.  Rocky head that left a lace on the glass.  Multi dimensional with flavors of coffee and some chocolate, finished with sour fruit.  Somewhat thin.  Rich.

Lucky to find a single bottle of this brew a month a ago, so since it will not be released this year, I decided to finish the night with it. Very dark brown hue with reddish crown. Medium tan head and very good lace. The aroma was espresso, semi-sweet chocolate, woody and earthy tones, and mild aromatic hops. Big sweet taste initially that blended into balanced smooth finish with a touch of oak smoke. Dry and lush mouthfeel with a medium body. I really enjoyed this a wish I had more, maybe Bells will brew this again next year.
Great dark color.  The flavor has a hint of sweetness.  Roasted malt leaves a nice clean taste in your mouth.  Good stuff... I must say.

opaque deep brown, beige head.  nice aroma of chocolate covered wafers, coffee, roasted malt, and a hint of petrol.  good follow through in the flavour and a nice dry finish.  what guinness wants to be when it grows up.
Dark brown, tan foamy head. Recognizable as a stout with cocoa/coffee overtones, but at the same time unique with a lighter body and clean finish. A nice creation, enjoyed very much.
Deep toasted nutty flavor, thick on the palate with a clean finish lingering of the wooded essence I so dearly dissolved within.
Liquid toast -- light in colour, sharply carbonated, no strong flavours in any direction.  Stout junior -- a good trial stout for otherwise lighter beer drinkers.

This is by far the lightest (colour) stout I've ever seen. On appearance alone it could be labelled a Brown Ale, but it definitely tastes like a stout. Great grainy, roasty flavours at a fairly mild level. Slight acidity and prickly carbonation with solid bitterness and dry finish. Good stuff!

A dark brown stout with light tan head, the aroma is a mixture of grain and coffee.  Flavor is well balanced between the dry roast flavors and others.  This is one of the better dry stouts around, in my opinion.

The colour is dark brown, but actually pretty light for a stout. The head was a nice fluffy slightly light brown and left a decent lacing on the side of the glass. The Smell is definately malty, malty and more malty. Some chocolate and coffee notes, but other than that, not much else. The taste is pretty light bodied (once again, especially for a stout) and is pretty simple: malt and a bit of bittering flavours (coffee and chocolate). Decent beer, but I actually expected more from the first Bell's beer I've had...I guess I've got two more to look forward to: Expedition & Third Coast Old. I got this at Merchant's in Dearborn, Michigan in a 12 ounce bottle.

Interesting!
Not a very dark stout. Burnt orange in color. Small, creamy, khaki-colored head. Decent lacing.
The aroma is of coffee and earth with a touch of chocolate and brown sugar/cinnamon thrown in.
Perfectly balanced flavor. Heavy with coffee and American White Oak. Medium-bodied with a slightly oily mouthfeel and lively carbonation. 
Coffee-heavy, lightly bitter finish. Nice brew!

Looks like pumpernickel bread, and tastes like French roasted coffee.  Strong java and dark brown sugar aroma, and very dry taste, but not bitter and not at all sweet.   My only issue with Trumpeters is that it 's too thin for a stout.  But still, it's quite good and well-balanced.  Truthfully, I think it tastes more like coffee than their Java Stout!

UPDATED: FEB 3, 2006 2002 draft.  Wasnt sure what to expect when told this was a lighter version of the Kalamazoo Stout.  It had some light chocolate notes and the tones were warm. Reminded me of a porter minus the bitterness.  Good beer, nothing exceptional, could use some more complexity, but certainly a well made ale.2002 bottle consumed on 2/2/06  A badly needed rerate.  The pour still showed plenty of signs of life, a rich caramel-toffee colored body, vigorous, large head that was slowly receding to cover.  Light lacing and well unfiltered.  The nose has light prunes and touches of dry coffee, but is mainly rich, thick, earthy barley, with a touch of bakers chocolate.  The flavor has held up remarkably for 3.5 years in the bottle.  Little to no oxidation, just some light madeira at best.  Rich chocolate and barley, more crunchy, dry coffee and a smooth toffee-cream finish with little bits of bitter black chocolate to keep things interesting.  Soothing mouthfeel and a rich consistency, almost fluffy.  Rating is for this sample, as I dont really trust any of my ratings back when I had this first.

Thinish black-orange at the edge. Pretty darn thin head. Aroma was pungent brownie- not chocolate, but cocoa. Very "baked", slight cinnamon. Great deoth to start. All those aroma qualities coming through on the tongue. I can't stress the wonderful depth enough. Good chocolate loveliness.

Somewhat muddy brown/black, smallish head.  Wonderful aroma, deeply chocolaty, lightly roasty and a bit bready.  Flavor pretty special too, nice sweet/dry balance, nice chocolate maltiness, some light fruit hints (raspberries?), extremely smooth, low carbonation, just enough hops at the end.  Another typically great product from Kalamazoo.

This beer poured a dark amber color, almost black and formed a off white foamy head that let circular lace as is subsided. An aroma of malt, coffee and chocolate. It has a flavor of malt, burnt coffee and chocolate. Some of that burnt aspect comes through in the astrigent finish, which is fairly light for this style.

This is a light colored stout with amber shallows and a smooth creamy head. While I was at first taken back by the light color, the flavor rectified my hasty judgement. Dry but not rough, the flavor explodes with burnt chocolate and musty overtones and finishs with just the right balance of hops and dark malt into post coital bliss. Trumpeter stout has every right to toot is own horn.

Rich malty aroma of chocolate and coffee.  Dark red-brown color, light tan head.  Flavor is malty, decent coffee flavor and a little chocolate.  On the light side, in both flavor and body.  Good session stout.

UPDATED: JUN 4, 2003 This brew pours with a very small light brown head. The body is very dark almost pitch black in color. It has a very strong coffee aroma from which you can almost smell the thickness. It also has a very strong coffee flavor. With in a few sips, you can feel the alcohol content in this brew.

Reading through the other comments, I was suprised to read how many folks commented on how dark this brew is.  This is the only Bell's stout that allows light to travel through it.  Thin chocolate brown with a tiny (and quickly dissolving) head.  No missing the java in the nose, but there is also a burnt quality to it.  The flavor is suprisingly light, with the roasted malts doing most of the work.  A little thin in the palate, but the dry-ness is perfect.  This is the stout to toast with on St. Patricks -- luckily I have 5 more.
Very dry and very espresso/coffee flavored.  Great warm dark chocolate feel.

This exceptionally dry Stout pours a dark mahogany color with a thin but dense beige head and thin lacing. Aroma of chocolate, coffee and roasted nuts. Flavors of coffee, dark chocolate, roasted grain/nuts and a little malt. The finish is a little thin, especially for a Bell's Stout and is mostly coffee. Still another good Stout from Bell's.

Here is a quality dry stout.  Try this one along with a Double Cream Stout to compare the two styles.  This is my favorite of the "November Stouts."  Trumpeter's Stout doesn't rival Kalamazoo, Double Cream, or Expedition Stouts, yet it makes a nice companion beer.

dark as a wet muskrat, but it'll reveal some ruby blush if pressed by fairly aggressive incandescence. a plop of shrinking foam, cashew colored. it's awash with micro-fine yeast particles like a teaspoon of dust from a belt sander. the description claims there's threeeeee different yeasts used--but hey, i only count TWO, what're they tryin' to pull here?   productive aroma generates rich earthy tones: coffee and composting banana peels, dark chocolate and burlap, lots of roasty tones and damp potting soil. flavor is real groovy, daddy-o, with smooth creamy feel, sweet at first, with dried plums marinated in coffee and pinot noir, a bit of slightly burnt fudge, and a chaw of dark leathery gaucho chaps. then marvel as the sweetness recedes before a gentle ebb of bitterness. very good session stout.

A good stout, black death of course.  Can taste a hint of chocolate and coffee.  It honestly tastes like Bell's Java Stout with a little less coffee.  That's not a terrible thing, I was just hoping for something obviously different.  This was close.  Still good.
Great coffee and slightly caramel like aroma.  Deep dark in color.  Very roasted flavor.  Dry finish

1/2/03 Dark brown color with ruby edges and a quick tan head. Could barely see through it. Aroma of chocolate, roasted coffee, and some hazelnut. Flavors of chocolate and burnt, roasty barley. Lingering aftertaste. Light mouthfeel and carbonation. Slightly acidic. A little thin for me.
Dark brown with a small white head and pretty heavy lacing. Funky coffee aroma. Flavor of nuts and coffee. Sligtly bitter finish.

This wasnt entirely dry - some mellow sweetness (dark fruit - maybe plum) and "woodiness" - o.k. maybe oak or pine - i dont know wood flavors.  Lots of spices in this, especially pepper.  I liked it, but it could be thicker.  (not that I would want "motor oil", just a little more to chew on please!)

My friend Portlandrunk got 5 Kalamazoo stouts in the mail and it was while drinking this one that I began to really notice the Kalmazoo signature taste: well roasted coffee and a touch smoky brown sugar or molasses. This beer was particularly dry (not like the rye or anything, but dry) and the signature maltiness blended really well with the rest of the beer. Not my favorite Kalamazoo but good nonetheless.

Probably the palest of the Bells stouts since you can actually see through this one. Great big roasty aroma, a bit of chocolate. Same in the flavor but a bit sour. Would be better if a bit richer and less sour.
Dark brown appearance.  Light milk chocolate in the nose, slight hint of coffee.  Body is spritzy, slightly hoppy, somewhat roasty. Finishes hoppy.  Nothing new here.
Brown, thin stout. Head didnt last. Coffee flavor dominates. Not much else flavor wise.

Dark but not opaque body with a thin, tan head.
Smelled like roasted coffee.
Tastes like roasted coffee with a bit of chocolate undertones. No hop presence in the taste.
Low carbonation and very creamy on the tongue.
Not a bad stout but I like the rye better for a dry stout.
Didnt like this one too much. Too much dryness from the coffee. Certainly not a very dark stout. Better than a lot of beers, but not a bells favorite.

Im on record as not liking dry stouts...even well-crafted ones! But this is a little bit different. Theres really fruit here (prune?)...not simply chocolate or coffeee notes; in fact, those seem subdued. I suppose this is off style in a relative lack of dryness but I liked it. Must be  the yeast strains.
user_location: Łódż, Warsaw, Poland; Michigan, Ohio, USA

text: Good strong dry roasted nut and coffee bean flavor.  But huge.  Maybe even too much healthy darkness here.  I confess I like quieter, gentler stouts.

Head is initially average sized, frothy, off-white, mostly diminishing. Body is hazy dark brown to black, dense tiny/small particles, bottle conditioned. Aroma is moderately malty (strong coffee, burnt grain). Flavor is moderately sweet, moderately bitter, lightly acidic. Finish is lightly sweet, lightly acidic, moderately bitter. Medium body, watery texture, lively carbonation. Fairly one-dimensional IMHO.
UPDATED: OCT 23, 2003 Beautiful color; thick head; coffee aroma with chocolate undertones. Smells better than it taste. Definately a beer that separates the men from the girls--and I am all girl.
user_location: Middle of no where, Ohio, USA

text: Muddy dark brown-black color, with a small tan head. roasty nutty, smokey aroma. Burnt malt, nutty roasty flavor has a sharp dryness in the end., has some sourness. medium body with a creamy, silky mouthfeel.
Had this and a Bells Rye Stout on the same night.  Both tasted very similar to me.  Somewhat watery with an average flavor.  Chocolate was the predominant flavor I could pick up upon first taste.

Big fat roasted coffee/cocoa nose.I like that this doesnt have the sourness that some of the other bells had.Tastes of chocolate and lattes. Didnt pick up the oak but whatever they did with this one they might want to try with some of the others. Thanks to hopsrus for this one!
Not much of an aroma.  I can really taste the chocolate in this one.  Its smooth and very lightly hopped.

The thinnest body of all the Bells stouts. Gerat sweet/bitter, dry, nutty, roasted aroma. The flavor was woody, roasted, with a strong nutty tone to it. Nice crisp, dry feel on the tongue. The color was medium brown, and I got no head off this one. Very nice coffee aftertaste. Im not usually a dry stout fanatic, but this is probably the best dry stout Ive had.

Muddy garnet colored out of the bottle with a root beer like head and a nose of roasted grain.  Very soft/creamy mouthfeel and a surprisingly light beer.  Almost chuggable for a stout.  Lots of roasted, dark malts with hints of bitter chacolate.  An easy stout for non-stout drinkers.
My favorite stout from Bells....so far.  Light to medium body.  Pronounced chocolate flavor, with bits of coffee and roastiness.  Low carbonation, dry and malty.  Great, great, great stout.

My favorite of the Bells seasonal stouts so far.  Great coffee flavor/aroma.  Pretty sweet for a dry stout but manages to stay on the safe side of cloying.  Thin, but flavorful. The head is as close to creamy as Bells gets, most of the heads on their beers are beady.  Pretty good.
almost opaque black, basically has no head. aroma and flavor are both big on the coffee...body is a little bit thin i think.
A rather smoky nose, with some almost petroleum-like funky notes. Flavor is very chocolatey and roasty, but its not too sweet at all. A great light gravity stout from the stoutmaster of Kalamazoo.
Dark brown body, pours with a decent head. Chocolate taste with decent bitter finish. Enjoy the Kalamazoo stout better but another fine Bells product.
Strong chocolate/coffee/espresso nose.   Medium bodied, dries off of the tongue at the finish.   Enjoyable, different.

I kinda expected this stout to be more hard-core but this one was good.  I dont know about any dryness. Tasted wet to me.  The color is blacker than cola.  The head is small and yellow. The first thing you taste apon drinking this stout is the coffee flavor.  Its different flavors blend together very nicely.I can definetly taste the hints of oak.  Ill have to try all the other november stouts!
For a stout, a fairly light body. Dark brown in color w/ a roasted coffee nose. Nice flavor, very drinkable

This was the second time that i had tasted this beer.  The first time i thought that it was disgusting.  However upon further inspection i came to realize what a truly great beer this was.  The taste was very chocolatey with something else that i cant quite explain.  I only wish that it had more head to make it feel more like a stout
Sweet malty aroma, clean, dry roasted flavour surrounded by coffee.  Pretty nice.

UPDATED: DEC 7, 2003 Ug, I must have gotten an old or bad batch, because it tasted like weak day-old coffee.  Not at all enjoyable.  I've got a sixer so I'll most definitely re-rate if the next gets any better.

Another excellent stout offering from Bells.  Pours out to a jet black color in the glass with virtually no head.  Taste is that of roasted malt, with slight coffee overtones.  A wonderful smooth, yet lightly hop-laden finish.
This must have been one of the first batches to come out.  Dark chocolate tones.  Not the best stout from Bells, but still rather good.

Dark and murky, try hard and youll get a small head.  Chalky, chocolate nose, like a Necco.  Smooth and sweet taste. Tastes of very expensive chocolate with a great dry hoppy end. This was a VERY young bottle, may get a point or two in aging.  This is part of Bells "Ten Stouts Of November". Enjoy!!

another winning stout from bells, dark brown with medium sized brown head, not an overly thick stout, but great aroma of roasted coffee. great mouthfeel of roasted caramel malt with a pleasant bitter hop finish, nice.

A brown stout which is sort of light in color.  A dark tan had poured about a half inch thick which disappeared quickly but left some nice lacing.  The aroma is like roasted coffee and soda crackers.  A bit of chocolate and a lot of dry come through in the mouth.  A bit thin, but enjoyable.  A nice level of bitterness in this dry stout.

Bottle.  A brown cola color with a thinly laced head.  The aroma is great, but the flavor is the exact same (which is not ideal).  It is a lighter stout, with coffee and bitter semi-sweet chocolate flavors.  Enjoyable.
A brown stout.   Black patent malt seems to give this beer its bitterness.  There also seems to be a sourmash quality to this one. A difficult on to figure out.

This is not a Pink Floyd Stout.  This is backwoods mandolin and flying fiddle fare, a big thumping stand-up keeping time.  Huge smoky inhale so you dont expect the hops to be such a force, but when they come - oh man!  Its like the banjo just opened up a wild solo.  The hops duel banjos with the smoky roast flavours, producing bitter fine edges.  Course, Im not always a banjo fan, and i dont always like a big hop presence in my stout.  But anyway, as far as Im concerned this is bluegrass beer.  But then, I play a lot of bluegrass outdoors in Michigan, and drink a lot of beer in the process, so Im a bit biased.  You guys who were looking for a beer to eat Pinconning cheese with?  This is it.
Not very thick for a stout.  Good balance of hops and roasted malts.  Very smooth mouthfeel.  It made me want to come back for more.  I am eager to try the other stouts from Bells.

Crackerlike, brown bread aroma. Well, when I get to the taste itself its like brown bread crust.  Not from your 7-Eleven loaf, I mean from the good stuff down at the expensive bakery that you only buy when you have guests over.  Lightish body, pretty typical stout flavours, no shortage of hops.  I have to be honest, I was more concerned with how well this was working with the Pink Floyd than I was with the beer itself.

Murky cola appearance with a thin but tight light tan head. Moderate carbonation. You can smell how dry this is. Roasted and bitter aroma with some java and nuts. Very dry, bubbly but with a solid malt base. Not thickly flavored but it is a dry stout. Nice lingering malt flavor, roasted, dry nuts. I do not like the sourish aspect of this and some other Bells stouts. Yeast maybe? Thanks Trap.

A dry/Irish stout indeed.  Roasty malt aroma (like a camp fire?) with hops well hidden, yet noticeable.  Silky mouthfeel and not as heavy as I would have preferred.  Light brown with little head retention.  Finish is semi-dry and round.  Whaddaya know, another well-made stout from this nice brewery.
user_location: Blue Ridge Mountains, North Carolina, USA

text: This beer is absolutely fabulous.  The flavors attack your tongue as in a tidal wave.  Hops, roasted malt and grain flavor all hit you at once with rippling backcurrents of wonderful malt complexity.  The finish is incredibly tight, everything coming back together at the end leaving your mouth hanging in anticipation for the next sip.  An absolutely amazing bottled stout.

(12-01 re-rate) My original rating was a little low so I bumped it up a bit after trying Trumpeters again.   
A dark, dry stout with a slightly bitter finish.   I found this stout to be a little hop heavy (relatively speaking).   It had a floral, burnt aroma and a silky, bubbly mouthfeel.   Another great Bells stout.
As I have said, I am not a stout nut, but this is Bells and they are turning me. A bit more bitter and more complex than Susies. I liked it not as much as Susies but still a great beer.
Great stout.  A bit of chocolate and coffee flavors.  I like it.
A thin and fairly bland malt with notes of black licorice in the aftertaste. Smooth, but not incredibly innovative.

Had this one directly after the Susies Sweet. A bit more of a bitter chocolate flavor and less of a malty sweetness than the Susie. Tasting all these stouts certaintly works on your tasting abilities.
Strong coffee flavor. Good stuff.
Sweeter than their Kalamazoo Stout. Strong coffee flavour, very good.
coffee ice cream, really good.  complex aroma, chocolate coffee taste. excellent
